course._descr: Chemical and physical properties of foods; issues pertaining to safety, nutritive value and consumer acceptability; government regulations pertaining to food safety, quality and additives; preservation techniques and transformation of agricultural commodities to food products; foods of the future.
course._prereqnote: At least second year standing required.

course._descr: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues.
course._prereqs: Either (a) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (b) all of KIN  190, KIN  191.

course._descr: Units and dimensions, mass balance, energy balance, steady state and transient heat flow, fluid handling and measurement.
Constituents of food and related chemical physical properties including water, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, minerals, and vitamins.
course._prereqs: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

course._descr: Principles of and procedures for analysis of the chemical and physical properties of food; proximate analysis; introduction to instrumental analysis; reporting and analysis of data.
course._prereqs: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

course._descr: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development.
course._prereqs: One of LFS  252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200.

course._descr: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions.

Microorganisms of importance in safety, spoilage and preservation of foods; factors affecting growth, survival and inactivation of microorganisms in fermented food systems; food processing plant cleaning and sanitation.
Integrated laboratory introducing techniques used in food processing and analysis. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.
course._prereqnote: These courses can be taken as corequisites.

course._descr: Integrated laboratory encompassing the processing and analysis of foods.  Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.

Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation.

Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis.
Principles of food preparation based on the physical and chemical properties of food.
course._prereqs: FNH  200 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123.

course._descr: Experimental and practical application of scientific principles and theories to problems of food preparation. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe I certificate.

course._title: Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
course._descr: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces.
course._prereqnote: At least third year standing required.

course._descr: Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism.
course._prereqs: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

course._descr: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health.
course._prereqs: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

course._descr: Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world.
The use of dietary, anthropometric, biochemical, and related information for the assessment of nutritional status of individuals and populations.

course._title: Human Nutrition Over The Life Span
course._descr: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span.
Introduction to the profession of dietetics in Canada. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.
Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program.
course._prereqs: FNH  250 and either (a) LFS  252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

course._descr: Functional food and nutraceutical concepts related to ingredient safety and quality; examples of nutrient-disease relationships, requirements for standards of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional food and nutraceutical industries.

course._title: Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
course._descr: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance.

course._title: Microbiology of Food and Beverage Fermentation
course._descr: Fermentation methods, mechanism and microbiology of nonalcoholic fermented foods and alcoholic fermented beverages (beer, cider, sake).
course._prereqs: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, BIOL 201, BIOL 203, BIOC 203.

course._descr: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety.

course._title: Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
course._descr: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515.
course._prereqnote: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.

course._descr: Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry.
Global transcript, protein and metabolite profiling technologies, their integration, application, and furtherance of our understanding of how higher organisms function in general.

Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. Restricted to students in the Dietetics major. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe II certificate.

course._title: Nutrient Metabolism and Implications for Health
course._descr: Integration of nutrient and energy metabolism on a whole-body and individual tissue basis and the implication for health. Emphasis will be on regulation of nutrient metabolism.

Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings.  Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs.

Etiology and pathophysiology of and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions, and skill development related to the Nutrition Care Process. Restricted to students in year 4 of the Dietetics Major.
Metabolic adaptations, nutrient metabolism, and special issues during pregnancy that may influence the maternal-fetal nutritional supply.

Theory and methods in public health nutrition and health promotion program planning to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate nutrition-related programs for communities and populations. Considers factors affecting behavior and the social determinants of health.

Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations.

Etiology and pathophysiology of and nutrition therapy for additional diseases and conditions, and further skill development related to the Nutrition Care Process. Restricted to students in year 4 of the Dietetics Major.
Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease.
Themes include practice-based research, clinical practice readiness, and orientation to internship.
course._prereqnote: Fourth-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

course._descr: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.
course._prereqnote: Fifth-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

course._descr: Full-time internship placements within British Columbia health authorities. Pass/Fail.

course._title: Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health - DST FOOD,NTR HLT
Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health - DST FOOD,NTR HLT
Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health - DST FOOD,NTR HLT

comment._text: Pre-requisite: approval of a program advisor; consult before the end  of classes in third year.

course._descr: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to preparation of a thesis.
course._prereqnote: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.
